content.description: This is a great, short, sport route for those who are just beginning.
content.protection: 3 bolts.
content.location: Head up the river from the main west side climbing.  Climb up the gully and it's at the terrace above the gully.

content.description: Climb a slab past some bolts to a roof, then through the crux on thin holds and continue up the face and arete to the top.
content.protection: Bolts.
content.location: Climb out the left side of the large roof.

content.description:
Start just to the right of

Finding Forester

.  Climb past some bolts to a short section of crack then through a bulge and up the face past more bolts to a fixed anchor at the top.
content.protection: Bolts & #1 Camalot.
content.location: This is the third route upstream from the fixed rope.

content.description:
This is the first route to the right of

Chucky Bill

and the large roof. It consists of face climbing past bolts to a crack that leads to the top.
content.protection: Bolts & gear.
content.location: This is right of the large, prominent roof.

content.description:
This route is an awesome face climb. The rating is steep, because it is a techy route where your sequencing matters!

The crux is between the 5th and 6th bolt at the small roof! The feet are small, but there are two small indents into the rock to put your big toe. Step up to a higher left foot, reach for the roof corner, and layback into it! Move your right foot to a smear, and put the left around the ledge to another smear. It is a pretty sweet move to get to the underclinging roof for a quick 6th bolt clip!

Luckily, the route is sustained, so be ready to grab some slope and get balancy!
content.protection: It is a well-bolted face climb. There are no chains for the anchor, but there are bolts! If I am recalling correctly, there are 9 bolts to the anchor.
content.location:
Keep walking on the climber's trail past the "Flying Dutchman" and "

Cape of Good Hope

". If you have made it to the area with "

Excited Delirium

", you have gone too far.

There are two random routes before this cliff, both less than 40 feet and with only two bolts. If you find those, walk around the gully to the cliff, and you will find the wall. However, look over the cliff to find the bolts!

content.description:
This is a fun, beginner route with a very easy (5.1) start for the first 15 feet before the actual climbing begins. The crux is about 2/3's of the way up.  It is a fun warm-up climb.

Update from Dalton Johnson: there are three potential variations of this route beginning at the second mantel. I did them all on TR solo, so I do not know what the pro situation is like. No offense, but this route, with everything on, is no harder than a 5.7.

Var1: only use the fist crack, the middle crack on the right side of the dihedral, until the crack disappears. From there, move back onto the face and pull the roof moves. This variation makes the route 5.8 (potential pro: cams 1-4).

Var2: only use the face and left side arete. The arete will be overhanging and dirty for a little bit. Move to the arete once the face is a flat undercling. Move back to the face of the route for the last bolt. Then finish this route, 5.9+/10-.

Var3: only use the face and lieback within the dihedral! This make the route 5.9 and is a blast! If one could pull the face moves off only, I would like the beta. I do not think pro would change for this route.
content.protection: It has 2 bolts and needs gear, and it has two anchors at top for toproping.
content.location:
This is about 40 feet up the river from

Chucky Bill

.

content.description: Follow bolts up through the big roof then start pluggin' gear in the shallow, meandering crack on an otherwise clean face (very sustained).  Fight to protect the crux.
content.protection: Quickdraws, standard climbing rack, off-set stoppers are useful, and a 60m rope.
content.location: This route is about a half mile up river from the main climbing area.  Walk along the canyon rim then descend down a drainage marked by a cairn.  Once you get cliffed out, shimmy left to a two bolt anchor w/ chains.

climbs.name: Prow Hugger
climbs.fa: I. Altman, K. Allinger, B. Murdoc, Sept. 25th, 2016

content.description:
This is an enjoyable longer route that ends well on a slightly overhanging prow with good exposure.

Start with blocky step-ups, and follow bolt line through easier terrain on Lemon-like choss (bolts 1-2).

Stay right at 3rd bolt and out of crack

and vegetated corner

following positive holds into steeper, yet still fairly moderate terrain (bolts 4-6). Join a slightly overhanging arete or prow, and stay on the thing, finding the crux just above the roof (bolts 7-9). This has cool positioning up top with a Lemonesque sequence that gets easier the more you climb it.

This route is fresh, so expect a bit of dirt on the ledges for the next year or so. It has fairly decent rock, with the best of it on the top half of this longer pitch.
content.protection: 10 QDs with 2 bolt chained anchor. Please DON'T TAKE LOWERING BINERS from the chains!
content.location:
It is visible from the Dog Gully approach as you descend to the creek... just right of the

Chucky Bill

buttress.

content.description: Stickclip the first bolt, unless this is comfortable terrain for you, then stem up the dihedral, and traverse right a couple moves. Then climb up through the initial bulge, and gain easier ground for a couple sequences. The main crux comes in moving through the second overhang of the next roof series and onto features above it. After executing the crux, climb up through some technical moves toward a left-facing dihedral that’s to your right and up through that to surmount another roof, which will deposit you onto the final, slabby stretch to the anchors. Above this stance is a massive, left-facing flake that begins from your right and diagonals leftward across the route: snatch this up, and take it to the chains. The difficulty of a couple of the crux moves are somewhat height-dependent and will feel anywhere from middle-11 to 11-plus once you’ve deciphered the beta. Enjoy!
content.protection: 1/2 in. stainless bolts to chain anchors with biners.
content.location: It is located further upstream from the main west side routes, past the tyrolean. The best approach is to cross to the east side, hike past the wall that houses Holy Grail and Brady’s, continue a short distance upstream passing a large, fallen tree that bridges the river, and up partially over the following talus mound then look for a rock path through the river to a small, rocky platform on the opposite (west) side just below the route. It’s easier to identify the route before crossing the river: look for a right-facing dihedral on the ground, which is the start of the route, that terminates in a roof. Several small roofs throughout the route characterize it as well. During high water, it may be inaccessible.

content.description: Climb the dirty, low-angle groove to the steeper and cleaner offwidth crack. Finish at a bolted anchor.
content.protection: #4 - #6 Camalot.
content.location: Past most of the routes, go up the hill on the right end of the cliff, this is the obvious wide crack.

content.description: Steep and sustained climbing up to the roof leads to a slightly runout face and a tricky move to the top.  It is destined to become a Durango classic!
content.protection: Bolts.
content.location:
This is upstream to the left of

Ball Chopper

.  It is the obvious steep bolt line through the roof.

content.description: The majority of the climbing on this pitch is quite pleasant, with good holds and rests throughout. Most of the climb is 5.8-5.9 with two 5.10 cruxes: one at bolt # 6 and one at bolt #8.
content.protection:
10 QDs are needed. If you clip the first bolt of

Bonsai

, then you'll need 11 QDs to make it to the anchor.
content.location:
It is located within the cluster of more moderate routes on the West Side. More precisely, it's 10 feet south or climber's left of

Bonsai

.

content.description: This is the second route to the right of the large roof. It was done all on gear.
content.protection:
Standard rack.

Per

George Bracksieck

: the first third is now protected by

Prow Hugger's

bolts.
content.location:
This is right of

Chucky Bill

and

Unnamed

.

content.description:
Climb compact granite clipping bolts to the roof.  Pull through the strenuous roof crux moves and now that you are well above your last bolt reach for your gear.  The climbing is easier (5.9 ish) and pretty much adequately protected.  Traverse slightly left and follow cracks to fixed anchor at top.

This is a good mix of physical and mental fun.
content.protection: One of everything to #3 Camalot, although one larger cam might be helpful.
content.location: This route is left of center on the chunk of rock with the large roof about 100 yards upstream from the knotted rope.  Look for bolts leading to a weakness in the roof.

content.description: This is a good pitch of moderate, fun, face climbing that leads to the top of the wall.
content.protection:
Bolts.  Per

Dylan Weldin

: bring a 0.75 to protect crux.
content.location: This is the second route upstream from the knotted rope.

content.description: This is a well-bolted, super-fun climb.  It's still a little dirty since it's a new route, so be careful!
content.protection: Twelve bolts to a bolted anchor.
content.location:
It is the first route at the bottom of the knotted rope.  It is left of

Finding Forester

.

content.description: This route is knd of spicy. It was put up on lead, so be prepared to run it out. The first 15 feet is a little dirty, but the rock is great from there on. It is spicy getting to the bolt if you are short like me. The crux is after the bolt. It is really fun, though....
content.protection: Cams of #2 Camalot and down. Bring doubles of #0.5 and down.  There is 1 bolt 3/4 way up and chained anchors.
content.location:
This route is 40 feet downstream from

NoJo

,

Ball Chopper

,

Slope Style

, etc.... It sits just above the large boulder on the river below and to the left of the talus field, 5 feet right of bolted 12a arete by Marcus Garcia. Hike the river in the Summer or rap from the top from multiple stations. Many more climbs are going up around these monolythic walls. Stay tuned and pics to come. Get on these routes, people!

content.description:
Start up

Ballchopper

and continue up the dihedral, pull the roof and finish on

NoJo

.
content.protection: Bolts and a few cams.

content.description: Climb past bolts and gear placements to a two-bolt anchor with slings and rings that are too flimsy for toproping. The rock is generally chossy and loose, but the climbing is interesting.
content.protection:
Bolts. You could place #0.4-2 Cams and large-ish Stoppers in sometimes-fragile rock.

Per

Steve Elder

: the anchor is now upgraded with chains and quicklinks.
content.location:
This is on the right side of the giant chimney that borders

Vertical Alluvium

. It is across that chimney from

VA

.

content.description: Climb past a few bolts to reach a left-facing crack.  Follow the crack to a small roof/bulge.  The crack widens and leads through the steep section, then continue up the wall passing the occasional bolt supplemented with some gear.  There is a fixed chain anchor at the top.
content.protection: Bolts & a few mid-sized Camalots.
content.location: This ascends the right side of the prominent, large roof.

content.description: Located on a prominent prow I like to call "The Flying Dutchman", 'Cape Point' ascends the right side of this feature. Start directly under a high roof and to the right of a small bulge/nose feature. Climb up to a good foot ledge and reach out left to clip the 1st bolt. Work left to the bulge/nose feature, possibly moving downwards a bit. Pull/mantle onto the bulge/nose feature and find a great left-hand jug to clip the 2nd bolt. Move out right to the high roof and work through the first and easier crux of pulling onto the ledge above the roof, where a good rest presents itself. Another crux appears between the 3rd and 4th bolts. Follow 2 more bolts to some easier traditional climbing up cracks and blocks. There are some fun exit moves to get to a 2-bolt anchor with chains and quick-links.
content.protection: 6 bolts for the bottom half of the climb leads you to easier traditional climbing for the second half. A light rack of cams up to #1 BD C4, a single set of nuts, and slings will get you to the top. A nice 2-bolt anchor with chains and quick-links are at the top to rappel down.
content.location:
From the Main Wall on the West Side, go North (upstream) about 100 meters. You can't miss "The Flying Dutchman", a prominent prow on the West Side. This route is just to the right of '

Cape of Good Hope

' and about halfway between the Main Wall and '

NoJo

'.

content.description: Located on a prominent prow I like to call "The Flying Dutchman", 'Cape of Good Hope' ascends the left side of this feature. Easy and enjoyable climbing leads to a high 1st bolt. Continue upwards, following the bolt line or just right of the bolts. The crux presents itself around the 4th and 5th bolts with a puzzling transition up to the 6th bolt. After clipping the 6th bolt, head right to a nice crack and a good rest. From here, it's easier traditional climbing up cracks and blocks. There are some fun exit moves to get to a 2-bolt anchor with chains and quick-links.
content.protection: 6 bolts for the bottom half of the climb leads you to easier traditional climbing for the second half. A light rack of cams up to #3 BD C4, a single set of nuts, and slings will get you to the top. A nice 2-bolt anchor with chains and quick-links are at the top to rappel down.
content.location:
From the Main Wall on the West Side, go North (upstream) about 100 meters. You can't miss "The Flying Dutchman", a prominent prow on the West Side. This route is just to the left of '

Cape Point

' and about halfway between the Main Wall and '

NoJo

'.

content.description: This is a long and enjoyable outing with a tricky crux at about 1/3 height.  If it feels harder than 10a, you likely got the tricky sequence wrong.
content.protection: Draws.
content.location: This is ~75 feet up river from the knotted rope.  The start is easy to find- it is a low angle slab/separate block with a Fixe SS bolt so low it could practically be clipped from the ground with an easy runout to bolt #2 above.

content.description: Climbing past bolts through fun bulges leads to a gear finish on deceptive cracks.
content.protection: Bolts and single set of cams.
content.location:
This is upstream, next to

Slopestyle

.

content.description:
Like

Wildflower

, it's another good, beginner, sport route.
content.protection: 3 bolts.
content.location:
This is just to the right of

Wildflower

.
